descendants.content:
@breadandcircuses it is actually one of most difficult subjects re global climate change. We are at the chaotic sea, nothing is certain. Someone has to instill authority not to fall apart.
So I understand them. However I also believe they fight losing battle, considering problems are pretty fundamental.
And finally, they can't solve this on their own. No one can.

account.note: Balamute, mūziķis, pārāk jūtīgs cilvēks - Chatterbox, musician by heart, programming / devops / design at Frontier Developments

descendants.content:
@breadandcircuses I agree totally.

Toxic positivity, stubborn optimism, yes-we-can attitude costs us years of real action.

These scientists are heard by politicians, corporate leaders, even COP because they confirm what they need to hear: That BAU can go on, we just need fixes here and there.

Truth is we’re heading to climate hell. Failures must be acknowledged. Big failures. There are responsibilities to address. Only then we have a chance to turn course radically.

descendants.content:
@breadandcircuses

“Now, there is some potential that your car has been replaced by a faster, better car. There's some potential that you will hit no traffic on the way to school. But, these are things you've never seen happen before, so they're very unlikely, right?”

Maybe also stop driving the kid to school,
stick him on a school bus, which might require being ready to go earlier (which can act as a new set of conditions that increases the likelihood the kid gets to school on time).

I know it’s being used as an analogy, but boy does the choice of analogy sometimes say a lot…

descendants.content:
@scottmatter @breadandcircuses

Good point.

There may be many reasons the kids are driven to school, but this only underlines one of the main changes needed if we are to successfully mitigate and/or adapt to our changing planet - we must all reconfigure our lifestyles for any measure of mitigation to be even halfway successful.

The biggest change imo being - reduce our energy consumption on all levels.

account.note:
🌏 Born at 312 PPM

Retired NGO executive doing my best to stay informed and raise awareness about environmental crises, climate breakdown, and the rapacious, murderous impact of greedy capitalists and the politicians they own.

Why the name? Back in the day, empires placated their citizens with "bread and circuses." Now we get fast food and apps. But it's all basically the same — distraction from what's REALLY happening.

descendants.content:
@breadandcircuses
I remember an interview with Professor Kevin Anderson back 5-7 years ago on YT and he was asked who he "blamed"; his list then was economists (neo classical eg Nordhaus etal) , then Climate scientists (or the senior ones at least who pander to the polticans he qualified that with), then journalists, then voters.

It was an interesting take and one I mostly agree with, albiet I'd put voters first.

descendants.content: @breadandcircuses True and I really can understand all the reasons. On the other hand: We are talking to adults and should respect their responsibility. The humans living in industrialised counties today are responsible for the biggest part of the global warming. And now, we try to deny our guilt. That simply is irresponsible behaviour.
